Anti-Piracy Measures: Digital Rights Management (DRM) for protecting downloadable study materials like PDFs and videos. User Experience: User-friendly and responsive interface for seamless navigation and interaction across devices. Restricting right-click, Ctrl+C, and screenshot functionalities to prevent unauthorized copying of content. Implementing Google reCAPTCHA to prevent spam and bot submissions. Upselling and Recommendations: Upselling additional study materials, courses, or premium features based on user behavior and preferences. Non-Functional Requirements: Performance: Fast loading times and responsiveness, even under high traffic conditions. Security: Implementation of best practices for securing user data, including encryption of sensitive information. Regular security audits and updates to patch vulnerabilities and ensure compliance with data protection regulations. Scalability: Designing the platform to scale horizontally and vertically to accommodate growing user base and content. Reliability: High availability and reliability with minimal downtime and robust error handling mechanisms. Monitoring and Analytics: Monitoring application performance, server metrics, and user interactions using tools like Google Analytics, New Relic, or Datadog. Logging and tracking user activities for audit trails and analysis. Constraints: Budget: The development should adhere to the allocated budget constraints. Timeline: The project should be completed within the specified timeline for deployment. Compliance: Compliance with legal regulations such as GDPR and copyright laws must be ensured throughout development and operation. title: Platform LoRa Based, low cost IoT platform for Renewable Energy Generation Unit Monitoring  - Upwork
description: Utilizing ChirpStack, InfluxDB, Grafana, and Node-RED can significantly streamline the development of your IoT platform for renewable energy monitoring and supervisory control. Here's how you can integrate these technologies: Components: ChirpStack (LoRaWAN Network Server): Set up ChirpStack as your LoRaWAN network server to manage communication between LoRaWAN devices (sensor nodes) and your application. Configure ChirpStack to forward data to your application server. InfluxDB: Use InfluxDB as your time-series database to store sensor data collected from renewable energy generation units. Define appropriate schemas to organize and efficiently store your data. Grafana: Integrate Grafana with InfluxDB to visualize and analyze the data collected from the renewable energy generation units. Create dashboards to display real-time and historical data, including power output, temperature, voltage, and current. Node-RED: Utilize Node-RED for data processing, automation, and integration tasks. Implement flows to handle incoming data from ChirpStack, process it if necessary, and store it in InfluxDB. Set up additional flows for supervisory control tasks, such as load management or predictive maintenance. Integration Steps: ChirpStack Integration: Configure ChirpStack to forward data to your Node-RED instance using MQTT or HTTP integration. Set up MQTT or HTTP endpoints in Node-RED to receive data from ChirpStack. Node-RED Data Processing: Develop Node-RED flows to parse incoming data from ChirpStack, extract relevant information, and transform it if needed. Store the processed data into InfluxDB for long-term storage and analysis. InfluxDB and Grafana Integration: Configure Grafana to connect to InfluxDB as a data source. Create Grafana dashboards to visualize the data stored in InfluxDB, allowing users to monitor renewable energy generation units' performance. Supervisory Control with Node-RED: Implement Node-RED flows to perform supervisory control tasks based on the data collected. Use decision-making algorithms to optimize energy generation, manage loads, or trigger maintenance actions. Deployment: Deployment Architecture: Deploy ChirpStack, InfluxDB, Grafana, and Node-RED on appropriate infrastructure, considering scalability, reliability, and security requirements. Utilize containerization (e.g., Docker) and orchestration tools (e.g., Kubernetes) for efficient management and scaling of the components. Configuration and Testing: Configure each component according to your specific requirements and test the end-to-end functionality thoroughly. Ensure proper communication between ChirpStack, Node-RED, InfluxDB, and Grafana. Monitoring and Maintenance: Set up monitoring and alerting mechanisms to detect and respond to issues promptly. Regularly update and maintain the system to incorporate new features, security patches, and improvements. Community and Documentation: Community Engagement: Engage with the ChirpStack, InfluxDB, Grafana, and Node-RED communities for support, collaboration, and knowledge sharing. Contribute back to the open-source projects by sharing your experiences, reporting bugs, and contributing code improvements. Documentation: Document your integration process, configuration settings, and best practices for deploying and maintaining the IoT platform. Provide tutorials and guides to help others replicate and customize your setup for their renewable energy monitoring projects.Skills: Internet of Things, Electrical Engineering, Arduino, Electronic Design, Embedded System, Python, Raspberry Pi, C++

I tried to describe everything as detailed as possible and I even included examples or links to examples (i.e. Ansible roles and compose files). So most of the things probably won't need much investigation but it needs someone who will actually finish it and has some experience with Podman. The basic idea is to have an Ansible script to provision an Ubuntu 22.04 machine with rootless Podman ( https://podman.io/ ) services like these examples: - KanIDM for LDAP and OpenID Connect / OAuth / SSO - Bunkerweb ( https://github.com/bunkerity/bunkerweb#bunkerweb ) - Stalwart Mailserver ( https://stalw.art/ ) - the following apps: Grafana, VictoriaMetrics, Loki, GitLab, Healthchecks, Glitchtip, Mattermost, Vaultwarden, Nextcloud, AdGuardHome, Wireguard, OpenProject - the apps should use KanIDM as the backend for authentication - all of their dependencies (i.e. databases) This Ansible playbook should NOT use Kubernetes or Docker. The whole setup should have automated Letsencrypt configuration for all exposed ports. Privileged ports should be setup with port forwarding of the firewall so that the firewall forwards privileged ports to the unprivileged containers. If you are interested let me know what would be your offer and what your estimation for a delivery date would be. Some of the current issues: - Bunkerweb seem to have a permission issue ( `Wrong permissions on /data/cache (RWX needed for user nginx with uid 101 and gid 101)` ) - activating secrets is giving a permission issue (`Failed to set permissions on the temporary files Ansible needs to create when becoming an unprivileged user (rc: 1, err: chmod: invalid mode: '+a'`) - GitLab seems to fail with `Mixlib::ShellOut::ShellCommandFailed: rails_migration[gitlab-rails] (gitlab::database_migrations line 51) ha        │ d an error: Mixlib::ShellOut::ShellCommandFailed: bash_hide_env[migrate gitlab-rails database] (gitlab::database_migrations line 18) had an error: Mixlib::ShellOut::ShellCommandFa        │ iled: Expected process to exit with [0], but received '137'` Please tell my how much time you would need and on which date you would be able to finish the playbook.Skills: Ubuntu, Linux, Configuration Management, Deployment Automation, Ansible, DevOps, Linux System Administration

description: Senior Cloud Platform Engineer Location: Remote Company Overview: Neural Internet has built a subnetwork that integrates various cloud platforms (e.g., Runpod, Lambda, AWS) into a cohesive unit. Its purpose is to enable higher-level cloud platforms to offer seamless compute composability across different underlying platforms. With the proliferation of cloud platforms, there's a growing need for a subnetwork that can seamlessly integrate these platforms, allowing efficient resource sharing and allocation. This compute-composable subnet empowers nodes to contribute computational power, with validators ensuring the integrity and efficiency of the shared resources. Our goal with this project is to showcase the capabilities of the subnetwork by building the first cloud platform on top. Job Description: As a Senior Cloud Platform Engineer, you will be instrumental in both the design and development of our cloud platform, focusing particularly on integrating GPU and CPU resources from the Bittensor subnet. This role requires a unique blend of skills in cloud computing, decentralized networks, and blockchain technologies. Cron Configuration and Execution Review: Checking the Scheduler logs, manually running cron jobs, and reviewing the cron configurations for each SuiteCRM user. System Update and Recovery Efforts: Attempting to recover from an interrupted Debian update, including managing locked processes and reviewing the impact of security patches.
